awd_titl_txt: Towards Culturally Responsive and Computationally Rich Problem Based Learning for K-5 Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This project is supported through the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.

Native Americans are significantly underrepresented in computer science careers. However, studies show that early exposure to computer science allows underrepresented students to develop foundational computer science skills and consider future learning in computer science. This project is focused on developing culturally relevant pedagogy and problem-based learning for Native American students in computer science. The project would create an innovative activity focused on equity in Internet access and how the Internet works so students can learn about computer science in a meaningful context. The project will use a citizen science approach to engaging students in tasks that are important to their local communities. The proposed work is a small, researcher-practitioner partnership at the middle school level between a university and a local school district. The team members include teachers, computer scientists, and STEM education experts. The primary goal is to begin to develop methods for designing problem-based tasks that are culturally meaningful for upper elementary students. 

The project will develop and pilot a curriculum to help fifth grade students contribute to Internet availability maps by engaging with computer science and computational thinking concepts such as computer networking, data representation, data collection and analysis, and algorithmic thinking. The research-practitioner partnership will use a design-based implementation research model to study the design and implementation of the culturally meaningful curriculum with a particular focus on Native American students.  There are two research questions. (1) How do K-5 schools and teachers identify culturally responsive, computationally rich problems that lend themselves to rigorous problem-based learning in computer science and computational thinking? (2) What curricular and teacher development support is needed to enable K-5 teachers to engage all students (particularly Native American students) in problem-based learning that rigorously integrates computer science and computational thinking? The partnership will collect data about the activity design process, the partnership itself, and students’ learning and experience of computational thinking and computer science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Our project aimed to create a culturally-centered curriculum designed to introduce fifth grade students, particularly those from Native American communities, to computer networks and Internet measurement. The primary goal was to address digital inequity by empowering students with foundational knowledge of these essential topics while respecting and integrating their cultural backgrounds.

In collaboration with four fifth grade teachers at a school with a significant Native American student population, we co-designed a computer science (CS) curriculum that was both educational and culturally relevant. This curriculum not only introduces students to the concepts of computer networks and how the Internet works but also emphasizes the importance of Internet measurement and computer networks to addressing digital divide issues. By weaving in community-based perspectives, we ensured that the material was more engaging and relatable for the students. The curriculum is available for free to the public through our project website.

Beyond creating the curriculum, we also focused on providing teachers with the tools and support they needed to adapt existing CS curricula for Native American students. Many educators, particularly in schools serving predominantly Native American populations, face challenges when trying to integrate culturally relevant content into their lessons. To help address these challenges, we organized two workshops with 14 teachers from schools that primarily serve Native American students. During these workshops, we explored the specific needs of these teachers, discussed strategies for adapting and enriching CS curricula, and developed practical curriculum adaptation tools and processes. These resources were designed to help teachers create more inclusive, culturally responsive lessons in the future.

The curriculum adaptation tools, along with additional resources and insights gained from the workshops, are available on our project website for educators to access and utilize. Our hope is that these materials will empower teachers to not only teach computer science in ways that are engaging for Native American students but also contribute to creating more inclusive CS education for all students by grounding the significance of CS in local values.
